assessment_meta.title: Workplace Patterns Assessment
assessment_meta.description: Understand your behavioral patterns at work - how you collaborate, communicate, and contribute to your team

instructions.intro: This assessment helps you understand your natural patterns at work through real scenarios. There are no right or wrong answers - just choose the response that feels most like you.
instructions.response_format: Scenario-based: Choose the response that best matches how you'd naturally act
instructions.time_guidance: Take your time, but trust your first instinct. Most people complete this in 8-10 minutes.

questions.text: At a team meeting, one person is dominating the conversation and others are clearly uncomfortable. You:

options.text: Wait for someone else to say something
Try to redirect with a question to the group
Directly address the imbalance
Signal support to quieter team members nonverbally

questions.text: Your team is stuck on a decision and everyone is looking around waiting for someone to take charge. You:

options.text: Wait to see if anyone else will lead
Suggest we take a break to think it over
Ask what everyone thinks we should do
Step up and suggest a way forward

questions.text: Someone takes credit for your idea in a group setting. You:

options.text: Let it slide to avoid creating tension
Address it privately with them later
Mention it casually: "I'm glad my suggestion is resonating"
Immediately speak up: "Actually, that was my suggestion"

questions.text: The group is enthusiastically supporting an idea you think is fundamentally flawed. You:

options.text: Go along with it to maintain group harmony
Stay quiet but prepare for when it fails
Ask probing questions to help them see the issues
Respectfully present your concerns

questions.text: You're in a meeting where everyone is agreeing with the boss's bad idea. You:

options.text: Nod along like everyone else
Stay silent but look skeptical
Ask clarifying questions that expose the problems
Find a diplomatic way to raise concerns

questions.text: You made a mistake at work that no one noticed yet. You:

options.text: Wait to see if anyone notices first
Quietly fix it and hope no one finds out
Confide in a trusted colleague for advice
Immediately tell your boss and own up to it

questions.text: In a group discussion, you have a great point to make but several people are talking. You:

options.text: Let the moment pass rather than interrupt
Wait for a natural pause in conversation
Jump in when you can find an opening
Gesture or say "excuse me" to get attention

questions.text: A colleague consistently misses deadlines, affecting your work. You:

options.text: Complain to others but not address it directly
Work around it without saying anything
Mention it gently and offer to help
Have a direct conversation about the impact

questions.text: Your manager gives you critical feedback in front of the team. You:

options.text: Feel embarrassed and replay it all day
Get defensive and explain why they're wrong
Take it in stride and ask for specifics later
Thank them and immediately implement changes

questions.text: Your team is brainstorming and someone shares a wild, unconventional idea. You:

options.text: Point out why it won't work practically
Stay quiet and let others respond
Build on it with related creative ideas
Encourage them and ask them to elaborate

questions.text: You have a 2pm deadline but it's 11am and you're not quite done. You:

options.text: Panic and rush through the rest
Keep working at your normal pace
Ask for an extension
Stay calm, prioritize, and finish what matters most

questions.text: Your team is celebrating a win, but you know you didn't contribute as much as others. You:

options.text: Celebrate equally - you're part of the team
Participate but feel a bit guilty
Downplay your own involvement
Actively credit those who did the heavy lifting

questions.text: After a long meeting, you typically feel:

options.text: Drained and need time alone
Ready to process with a colleague
Neutral - back to work
Energized and ready to connect more

questions.text: You're assigned a project with completely new tools/systems you've never used. You:

options.text: Feel overwhelmed and anxious about learning
Prefer to stick with what you know
Feel a bit nervous but willing to try
Get excited about learning something new

questions.text: A team member is struggling with something you know how to do. You:

options.text: Wait for them to ask for help
Drop hints that you're available
Offer help proactively
Jump in and show them how to do it

questions.text: You discover your company is doing something you disagree with ethically. You:

options.text: Keep your head down - it's not your problem
Feel conflicted but stay silent
Discuss it with trusted colleagues first
Raise your concerns through proper channels

questions.text: Your boss asks you to take on extra work, but you're already stretched thin. You:

options.text: Say yes and figure it out later
Say yes but feel resentful
Explain your workload and ask what to deprioritize
Politely decline and explain your capacity

questions.text: Before a big presentation, you typically:

options.text: Feel sick with nerves and dread it
Feel butterflies but push through
Feel a bit nervous but mostly confident
Feel energized and excited to share

questions.text: Your team adopted a new process that you think is inefficient. You:

options.text: Follow it exactly as prescribed
Follow it but mentally check out
Test small improvements within the framework
Propose modifications based on what you're seeing

questions.text: You notice a mistake in work that's already been submitted to leadership. You:

options.text: Hope no one notices and let it go
Lose sleep over it but don't say anything
Quietly correct it if possible
Flag it immediately and offer to fix it

dimensions.name: Openness
dimensions.description: Curiosity, creativity, and willingness to try new approaches

interpretation.high: You're innovative and enjoy exploring new ideas. You bring fresh perspectives to your team and aren't afraid to challenge the status quo.
interpretation.medium: You balance traditional methods with occasional innovation. You're open to new ideas when they make sense.
interpretation.low: You prefer proven methods and consistent approaches at work. Stability and reliability are your strengths.

dimensions.name: Conscientiousness
dimensions.description: Organization, responsibility, and attention to detail

interpretation.high: You're highly organized, reliable, and take ownership seriously. Teams can count on you to deliver quality work and maintain high standards.
interpretation.medium: You balance structure with flexibility in your work approach. You're dependable when it matters most.
interpretation.low: You work best with flexibility and spontaneity. You may struggle with rigid processes but excel at adaptability.

dimensions.name: Extraversion
dimensions.description: Energy from social interaction and team engagement

interpretation.high: You're energized by teamwork and collaboration. You naturally engage with colleagues and thrive in group settings.
interpretation.medium: You enjoy both collaborative and independent work. You adapt your energy to the situation.
interpretation.low: You work best with focused solo time and may find constant interaction draining. Deep work is your sweet spot.

interpretation.high: You prioritize team harmony and are naturally empathetic. You're a strong mediator and people feel heard around you.
interpretation.medium: You balance team needs with your own boundaries. You're collaborative without being a pushover.
interpretation.low: You're comfortable with healthy conflict and setting firm boundaries. You prioritize directness over diplomacy.

dimensions.name: Emotional Stability
dimensions.description: Resilience under pressure and stress management

interpretation.high: You handle workplace stress well and maintain perspective during challenges. Pressure doesn't shake your confidence.
interpretation.medium: You experience normal workplace stress but generally manage it effectively. You have good coping strategies.
interpretation.low: You may be more sensitive to workplace stressors. Consider stress management support or coaching to build resilience.
